trial_identification.studytitle: Effects of vitamin D on insulin resistance and endothelial dysfunction in diabetic patients with ischemic heart disease
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effects of vitamin D administration vs. placebo on insulin resistance, endothelial dysfunction and inflammatory markers in diabetic patients with ischemic heart disease

interventions.interventions: Adminstration of a single dose parenteral vitamin D 300000 IU or placebo to diabetic patients with ischemic heart disease
interventions.comparator: Placebo contains all of the excipient in oil execpt the active substance vitamin D

primaryOutcome.outcome: Lowering Inflammatory marker, hs-CRP, based on measuring serum level
Improving insulin resistance based on HOMA-IR model

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Alleviation of endothelial function based on ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 measured level

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients with diagnosis of type 2 Diabetes mellitus on the basis of ADA criteria and ischemic heart disease based on angiography results
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. History of hypersensivity to Vitamin D 2. Renal failure 3.Hypercalcemia 4. Pregnant women 5. Lactating women 6.Hepatic failure (Child-Pugh B and C)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Hypovitaminosis D is a common problem and has negative effects on cardiovascular and metabolic disease like diabetes. So we want to try the effects of Vitamin D vs. placebo on inflammatory and cardiovascular markers and insulin resistance.
